Award.AwardTitle: Exploring the Causes for Indian Ocean Decadal Climate Variability
Award.AbstractNarration:
Decade-to-decade changes in the sea surface temperature (SST) of the Indian Ocean (IO) have been implicated in a variety of worldwide climatic fluctuations, including variations in Indian monsoon rainfall, changes in the frequency of cyclones in the Arabian Sea, and changes in drought frequency in the US, the Mediterranean, and parts of Africa. Averaged over the basin, IO SSTs have been increasing since the 1950s, often at a faster rate than SSTs in other tropical oceans, and have continued to increase even during the recent global warming hiatus. The goal of this research is to understand the mechanisms that produce decadal variability of IO SSTs and accompanying variations of sea level pressure (SLP), surface winds, and other meteorological conditions. A particular goal is to identify the separate roles of remote influences from the Pacific sector, and coupled ocean-atmosphere dynamics internal to the IO sector, in generating decadal IO SST variability. The Pacific influence is associated with the interdecadal Pacific oscillation (IPO), a slowly varying pattern of SST anomalies with some resemblance to the more rapidly evolving SSTs of El Nino/Southern Oscillation events. Previous work suggests that the positive phase of the IPO, when SSTs warm over the central equatorial Pacific, can produce uniform warming over the IO. The PI hypothesizes that the warming is caused by strengthening of the Walker circulation, which enhances subsidence over the IO and increases surface insolation by reducing cloudiness. But the more recent observational record shows a continued increase in mean IO SSTs even as the IPO has transitioned to its negative phase, so factors other than the IPO must also play a role in basin-wide IO warming and cooling. While the Pacific influence is linked to uniform SST anomalies, the IO basin contains a second prominent decadal variability mode which is largely independent of the IPO. This mode is an east-west pattern in which warm SSTs in the western half of the basin are accompanied by cold anomalies off the coast of Indonesia, referred to as the Indian Ocean dipole (IOD). The PI hypothesizes that the IOD is driven by coupled atmosphere-ocean dynamics in which subsurface heat transport plays a key role. In addition to attribution of IO variability in terms of internal dynamics and external influences from the Pacific, the project also seeks to understand the role of external forcing, including greenhouse gas-induced warming, solar variability, and anthropogenic aerosols. A variety of statical techniques are applied to diagnose the mechanisms of IO variability in observations, reanalysis products, and climate model simulations. In addition, specialized climate model experiments are performed in which atmosphere-ocean interactions are enabled only in the IO sector to determine the extent to which IO-sector dynamics can produce decadal variability. Complementary experiments are used to determine the extent to which decadal variability in the IO sector is due to coupled atmosphere-ocean dynamics external to the basin. Further climate model experiments examine the role of external forcing by imposing changes in greenhouse gases, aerosols, and solar irradiance.

The work is of societal as well as scientific interest given that that conditions in the Indian Ocean affect the weather and climate of the adjacent land region, which is home to perhaps a third of the world's population, much of it in developing countries with heightened vulnerability. Also, as noted above, there is evidence that the decadal variability of IO SSTs are linked to a variety of climatic impacts worldwide, including some that affect the US. In addition, the project would support and train a postdoc, thereby providing workforce development in this research area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
I. Science

Due to the societal need, understanding and predicting decadal climate variability emerge as one of today’s pressing priorities in climate research. Defining the limits of decadal predictability and developing models capable of skillful decadal predictions rely critically on our understanding of the causes for decadal variability, including contributions from external forcing (i.e. anthropogenic aerosols and greenhouse gases (GHG) and natural forcing by volcanoes and solar radiation) and natural internal variability of the climate system.

The Indian Ocean has received increasing attention recently because of its large impacts on regional and global climate particularly since the 1950s. The goal of this project is to obtain in-depth understanding of the Indian Ocean decadal climate variability, and investigate its causes. Below are the major outcomes from this NSF project.

Among the many new scientific results we have obtained, the most exciting aspects are summarized below.

1)    we identified a new coupled variability mode, referred to as the Indo-Pacific Warm Pool Dipole; its mechanisms involve inter-basin feedbacks between the Southeast Indian Ocean and central-western tropical Pacific, via both atmospheric bridge (teleconnection) and oceanic connection through the Indonesian Throughflow (ITF). The paper was highlighted by American Geophysical Union;

2)    During the 2003-2012 global surface warming hiatus period (i.e., the Earth’s surface temperature is not rising but excessive heat continues to enter Earth’s climate system), the surface and subsurface Indian Ocean store ~2/3 of the "missing" heat, through enhanced transport of the Indonesian Throughflow from the tropical western Pacific. Among the ~2/3 heat gain, ~66% was stored in the Southeast Indian Ocean off the west Australian coast region. This amount of heat again, however, is not purely from the ITF water; Indian Ocean air-sea feedback also plays a significant role.

3)    While the Interdecadal Pacific Oscillation (IPO) – the dominant decadal climate variability mode of the Pacific Ocean - induces significant decadal variability of Indian Ocean sea surface temperature (SST) before the mid-1980s, external forcings by volcanoes,  anthropogenic greenhouse gases and aerosols are the major causes for decadal Indian Ocean SST variability after the mid-1980s; the Indian Ocean SST anomalies in turn intensify the decadal variability of Pacific trade winds in the western equatorial basin, which subsequently force intensified Pacific variability and the Indonesian Throughflow.

II. Education

The project has provided career training for postdocs, Dr. Yuanlong Li, Gang Wang and Lei Zhang. Parts of the results were also discussed/presented in the classroom (upper division undergraduate & graduate course): “ATOC4800/5000: Policy implications of climate/Critical issues in climate and the environment” that the PI taught.

 III. Professional and Societal impacts

We are organizing a session at the AGU Fall Meeting of 2019 and a session at the AGU Ocean Sciences Meeting in 2020 to assemble researches for inter-basin interaction (AGU Fall 2019) and Indian Ocean variability as well as its role in global climate (AGU Ocean Sciences 2020). The research results were presented at national and international meetings and conferences, and were published in peer-reviewed professional journals.

The fact that most of the increased heat over the Indian Ocean was concentrated in a small region over the southeast Indian Ocean off the west Australian coast during the recent global surface warming hiatus decade is important for informing regional decision making regarding protecting marine ecosystems and predicting heat waves in Australia. The large amplitude sea level rise/fall on decadal and multidecadal timescales along the east coasts of the Indian Ocean (India, Bangladesh, Sotheast Asian, and west Australia) will help decision makers to make informed decisions.
